Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: iCER ACRES: iCER Advanced Computational Research Experience for Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research experience for undergraduates (REU) project aims to engage undergraduates in learning experiences that increase student's interest and ability to conduct computational and data science research in a range of scientific domains. The ability to effectively solve problems on high-performance computational resources is an area of increasing national importance. The educational process supported by iCER ACRES will enable students to address a range of computational projects of significant benefit to the US. In particular, computational science is now important in improving the health of the country, advancing our common prosperity and welfare and advancing the cyber-defense of the US. Projects provided through this site will advance the overall national skillset in the computational and data sciences field through hands-on educational activities. In addition to providing undergraduates with research learning experiences, this project will broaden the participation of underrepresented populations in STEM research, provide early HPC exposure to students from institutions with limited access to HPC resources, especially women and underrepresented groups and motivate students to pursue careers in computational fields.

The overarching goal of the program is to increase students' technical skillset to address in a broad range of computational fields. iCER ACRES achieves this goal by: (i) engaging undergraduates in original interdisciplinary collaborative research in data science and scientific computing domains; (ii) introducing students to a broad set of "classical" programming algorithms and their applications for problem-solving in data science and scientific computing; and (iii) exposing undergraduates to high performance computing (HPC) resources used to conduct research and software engineering practices applied to increase the quality of scientific applications. These program elements are designed to:
- Allow students to experience and learn about the research process through working on an unsolved, open-ended research problem;
- Increase participants' disciplinary knowledge and their understanding of how that knowledge may be applied;
- Assist students in defining and refining their research and career interests;
- Provide students with an introduction to the world of academia and graduate school; and
- Provide a forum for collegial interaction with a faculty member.
Research projects provided through this site focus on the development and enhancement of algorithms, models, and software for applications in multiple domains that require high performance resources. These domains include but are not limited to: computational chemistry, biology, astrophysics, mathematics, big data science, computational electromagnetics and cybersecurity. This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ACRES REU provided students with authentic and meaningful research experiences in computational or data science in disciplines such as astrophysics, earth science, medical imaging, forestry, chemistry, mathematics and biology; exposed them to a general set of technical skills related to computationally-focused research; and provided professional development that enhanced their summer experience and informed them about careers and graduate school opportunities, thus preparing them to be part of the 21st century workforce.

Intellectual Merit

Publications & Presentations. Products resulting from the award include 9 peer-reviewed journal articles, conference posters and workshops and software package contributions in the following disciplines: computational chemistry, computational biology, bioinformatics, forestry, and astrophysics. Additionally, initial datasets and software developed by REU students are currently used by lab groups to lay the foundation for future projects, including an R21 NIH-funded project.

Student Outcomes. Of the thirty-nine students supported by the award, 16 have now completed their undergraduate degrees. Of these 11 (~ 69%) have begun or completed computationally focused graduate degrees, 4 (25%) are currently pursuing careers in industry/research labs and the remainder are pursuing medically focused graduate degrees. Several students were awarded graduate scholarships, including the prestigious NSF Graduate Research Fellowship.

Career Impact. Participants indicated that the program helped to inform their choices after graduation, including providing valuable information about the expectations and the application process through their interactions with faculty members and graduate students. More specifically, program alumni in 2017 and 2018 cohorts indicated that they used their REU experience to think more critically about computational and data science research and their future plans in the following ways:

  • Broaden their concept of what they could do with a career in math/science including how their traditional STEM interests intersect with computing;

  • Expand the scope of their academic interests, by participation in original research projects in areas not available at their home institution or otherwise;

  • Learn and gain proficiency in technical and domain-specific skills through application to "real world" problems;

  • Understand the research process and gain practice using those skills; and

  • Clarify and confirm their career directions - many students viewed this as a test drive of graduate school, research, independent thinking

Gains in research and computational skills. Program participants reported feeling validated in their identity as researchers and as members of the research community. Mentors identified gains in participants' computational skills, including programming skills (e.g. bash and python), parallel computing, machine learning tools, deep learning techniques, modern development workflows and parallelizing codes. 

More specifically, the CISE REU pre- post- program survey showed significant gains in students' self efficacy and research skills, as well as improved help seeking and coping skills. While students reported improved ability to communicate across disciplines, due to the multidisciplinary nature of the program, which challenged them to work on projects in new disciplines and frequently communicate with team members from a variety of science backgrounds.

Broader Impacts: Over the course of three Summers, 345 students applied to the ACRES REU. Thirty nine students (∼ 11%) were selected to participate in the program. Of these 39 participants:

  • One third identified as female

  • Almost half (19) identified as URM (women or non-white/asian males). This is well above the 20-30% typical of CISE REUs

  • Over a third had just completed their freshman or sophomore year before applying to the program.

  • Over two-thirds (27) identified as pursuing STEM majors other than computer science

  • Over a fifth (8) were from universities not identified with very high/high research activity (i.e. R1/R2)

  • Over a fifth (8) self-identified as having no prior research experience

  • Only one student was from Michigan State University

Very few students entering the program had any familiarity with applying best practices for developing scientific software, using a computing cluster (or supercomputer) to access installed software and submit jobs and developing parallel codes and in some cohorts as many as two thirds left the program feeling familiar with them.
